comments:
run/debug profiles management is incoherent:
switching from a profile to another may not actualise all the fields in the
right panels, and may causes a save changes dialog to appear. If you click yes,
it may destoy parts of the profile. I had copy an old the .launches folder to
recover profiles.

Beside, this is way too hidden. Run profiles should be saved anywhere we want,
like when shared but not only in project folders.

You're going to have to be more specific. Since launch config delegates & tabs 
are contributed by plug-ins, the problem is often with the implementation of 
the contribution, not the framework. What tabs are causing problems?

All of them are slow, and I don't even touch the tabs nor a single option,
and it ask if I want to save.

I don't have any plugin other than  what comes with the zip.
Every tab is slow, but is may happend that it is fast by some magical touch (or
there is an exception, but where?).

There is no observable repeatable condition. Don't be afraid to profile the
performance while changing tabs or switching profiles on the left.

All I can say, is that I updated from m2 to m3, and had to copy the .launches/
(maybe some incompatibilities...?)

Anyway, if these launch profiles where more clear text xml, I would certainly
not waste my time editing through the ui (it is really not responsive, like 1
second or 2 between tabs or profiles, under a p3 866Mhz with plenty of memory,
and jdk 1.4).

Can someone show me how to run eclipse without eclipse.exe, but with plain java
command line with path and classpath? I want to debug&profile it, and maybe
catch some stacktrace...

You can start Eclipse using java from the command line the following way.  You
must execute this from the eclipse directory.

java -classpath startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main org.eclipse.ui -data
<path to your workspace>

If you run the above command on an empty (non-initialized) workspace, Eclipse
will initialize the workspace and exit.  You will not see a UI.  After that,
every time you run Eclipse on that workspace, you will see the UI.  This
(seemingly odd) behaviour is required by the Eclipse update/install story.

Are the stack traces you're pasting here caused by manual edits to launch
configuration XML files?

Also, a reproducible test case would be useful. At the very least, you need
to specify what kinds of launch configurations you're touching. On my machine
clicking between various Java Application and Runtime Workbench 
configurations takes is instantaneous.

Problems related to false "Unsaved changes" notification can always be reduced to a reproducible test case. The config framework has always been
extremely weak in this area, but these bugs are always easy to fix with a
test case.

I installed a brand new eclipse (2002 12 04). Runs better.
I never edited lauch files, but did copy them across versions.

The backward compatibility is absent? Or you rely on on data migration only once
at install? Whatever. I won't toy with that anymore. But the launch files should
be really more human readable, or straight binary with a good versionning mecanism.

The files are not intended to be human readable. If you want to "version" them, 
then you should make them shared - i.e. save them in your workspace. You can do 
this from the "common" tab.
We do not intend to change the fomat of launch files.
